title: A FUNERAL FOR THE MAIN
blurb: In 2012, community members held a funeral to protest and mourn the destruction of several historic buildings on lower St-Laurent. Built in the 1890s, the buildings had housed iconic businesses like the Montreal Pool Room and Épicerie Importations Main for decades. They had been bought out and were scheduled for demolition to make way for a new development. Only Café Cléopâtre successfully fought to stay. The mock funeral (RIP culture) was staged by artist and activists part of the Save the Main Coalition. It included a faux priest (Infringement Festival creator Donovan King), hysterical mourners (burlesque dancer Velma Candyass and others) and pall-bearers.

title: Mischief on The Main
blurb: In June 2020, Matt Carignan was charged with mischief under $5000 for painting a peace sign in Peace Park. He got charged when he returned to the scene of the crime with his bike, which happened to be painted the same color blue. Matt didn’t even know the park was named Peace Park — his peace sign design was coincidental. He almost painted Pac Man. Having been charged, Matt returned to finish his work the next day. He figured he had $4880 worth of credit since he was charged with mischief under $5000, but he only used $120 worth of spray paint.
